===Second incarceration===
===Second incarceration===
â
Fish remarried on February 6, 1930, in [[Waterloo, Iowa]], to an Estella Wilcox but divorced after only one week.<ref>{{Cite news |author= -Wife Unconcerned |url=http://select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F40B17F93558177A93C7A81789D95F408385F9 |quote=Mrs. Estella Wilcox of Waterloo, former wife of Albert Fish, said tonight that she did not care what happens to her former husband. ... |work=[[Associated Press]] in the [[New York Times]] |date=December 15, 1934 |accessdate=2010-03-29 | title=Ex-Wife Unconcerned}}</ref> Fish was later arrested in May 1930 for "sending an obscene letter to a woman who answered an advertisement for a maid."<ref name="NYT12151934"/> He had been sent to the [[Bellevue Hospital Center|Bellevue psychiatric hospital]] in 1930 and 1931 for observation, following his arrests.<ref name=took>{{Cite news |author= |title=Mr. and Mrs. Budd Name Him on Stand as One Who Took Child Away Before Murder |url=http://select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=FB0F11FE3B59107A93C1A81788D85F418385F9 |quote=The parents of 10-year-old Grace Budd identified Albert Fish today as the man ... He criticized psychiatrists of Bellevue and Kings County Hospitals for ... |work=[[New York Times]] |date=March 13, 1935 |accessdate=2010-03-29 }}</ref>
+
Fish remarried on February 6, 1930, in [[Waterloo, New York]], to an Estella Wilcox but divorced after only one week.<ref>{{Cite news |author= -Wife Unconcerned |url=http://select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F40B17F93558177A93C7A81789D95F408385F9 |quote=Mrs. Estella Wilcox of Waterloo, former wife of Albert Fish, said tonight that she did not care what happens to her former husband. ... |work=[[Associated Press]] in the [[New York Times]] |date=December 15, 1934 |accessdate=2010-03-29 | title=Ex-Wife Unconcerned}}</ref> Fish was later arrested in May 1930 for "sending an obscene letter to a woman who answered an advertisement for a maid."<ref name="NYT12151934"/> He had been sent to the [[Bellevue Hospital Center|Bellevue psychiatric hospital]] in 1930 and 1931 for observation, following his arrests.<ref name=took>{{Cite news |author= |title=Mr. and Mrs. Budd Name Him on Stand as One Who Took Child Away Before Murder |url=http://select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=FB0F11FE3B59107A93C1A81788D85F418385F9 |quote=The parents of 10-year-old Grace Budd identified Albert Fish today as the man ... He criticized psychiatrists of Bellevue and Kings County Hospitals for ... |work=[[New York Times]] |date=March 13, 1935 |accessdate=2010-03-29 }}</ref>
